unnormalised: Okay, here's the blog post you requested, playing with the topic of educational titles and achievements in a humorous, Indian-English style:
normalised: Okay, here's the normalized version of your blog post:

unnormalised: So, you've finally got that degree, huh? Congrats! Welcome to the club of overly-educated-but-still-figuring-things-out folks. I remember the day I got my 'B.Sc. (Hons)' – felt like I could conquer the world! Turns out, the world mostly needs someone to debug Javascript, not quote Shakespeare.
normalised: So, you've finally got that degree, huh? Congratulations! Welcome to the club of overly-educated-but-still-figuring-things-out folks. I remember the day I got my 'B-S-C (Honors)' – felt like I could conquer the world! Turns out, the world mostly needs someone to debug Javascript, not quote Shakespeare.

unnormalised: But hey, at least we have those fancy titles, right? All those years of studying for what? So you can sign your name "Mr. Rakesh Sharma, MBA" and feel marginally superior at the local chai stall. The chaiwala, bless his heart, probably doesn't care if you have a 'Ph.D. in Quantum Physics', as long as you pay the ₹10.
normalised: But hey, at least we have those fancy titles, right? All those years of studying for what? So you can sign your name "Mister Rakesh Sharma, M-B-A" and feel marginally superior at the local chai stall. The chaiwala, bless his heart, probably doesn't care if you have a 'P-H-D in Quantum Physics', as long as you pay the rupee ten.

unnormalised: Seriously though, all that 'Master's in Computer Applications' and 'Bachelor of Engineering' business sounds impressive until your mom asks you to fix the TV remote… and you stare blankly at it like it's a complex algorithm you can't quite crack. Then you realise that all those hours spent studying 'Data Structures' were probably less useful than learning how to replace the remote's batteries.
normalised: Seriously though, all that 'Master's in Computer Applications' and 'Bachelor of Engineering' business sounds impressive until your mom asks you to fix the T-V remote… and you stare blankly at it like it's a complex algorithm you can't quite crack. Then you realise that all those hours spent studying 'Data Structures' were probably less useful than learning how to replace the remote's batteries.

unnormalised: And let's not even get started on the post-graduation glow. You walk around like 'Dr. Priya Iyer', ready to cure all the world’s ills, only to be met with the reality of internship pay that barely covers your commute in a Mumbai local. But at least the "Dr." looks good on LinkedIn, eh?
normalised: And let's not even get started on the post-graduation glow. You walk around like 'Doctor Priya Iyer', ready to cure all the world’s ills, only to be met with the reality of internship pay that barely covers your commute in a Mumbai local. But at least the "Doctor" looks good on L-inked I-n, eh?

unnormalised: The best part is when your relatives get involved. "Oh, beta, you have a 'M.Tech from IIT Delhi'?! That's great! Now you can finally get a good job... and get married! What's the point of all those qualifications if you're not settled down by 28?" Ah, the joys of Indian families and their obsession with timelines.
normalised: The best part is when your relatives get involved. "Oh, beta, you have a 'M-Tech from I-I-T Delhi'?! That's great! Now you can finally get a good job... and get married! What's the point of all those qualifications if you're not settled down by twenty eight?" Ah, the joys of Indian families and their obsession with timelines.

unnormalised: But jokes aside, getting those degrees takes serious work. '10th standard' and '12th standard' board exams were no cakewalk. You pulled all-nighters, survived endless tuition classes, and probably lived on Maggi for a good portion of your student life. So, own that 'BA (History)' with pride! Even if all it qualifies you to do is argue about Bollywood movies with your friends.
normalised: But jokes aside, getting those degrees takes serious work. 'tenth standard' and 'twelfth standard' board exams were no cakewalk. You pulled all-nighters, survived endless tuition classes, and probably lived on Maggi for a good portion of your student life. So, own that 'B-A (History)' with pride! Even if all it qualifies you to do is argue about Bollywood movies with your friends.

unnormalised: So, to all my fellow degree-holders, lets remember that those 'Certificates of Completion' and 'Diplomas in Civil Engineering' represent dedication and perseverance. Embrace the irony of being overqualified and underpaid, and maybe, just maybe, we'll figure out how to use all this knowledge to, you know, actually do something useful. Or at least fix the damn TV remote.
normalised: So, to all my fellow degree-holders, let's remember that those 'Certificates of Completion' and 'Diplomas in Civil Engineering' represent dedication and perseverance. Embrace the irony of being overqualified and underpaid, and maybe, just maybe, we'll figure out how to use all this knowledge to, you know, actually do something useful. Or at least fix the damn T-V remote.

unnormalised: And if all else fails, you can always fall back on your extensive knowledge of Indian history, thanks to your B.A., and impress everyone at parties with your trivia! Just make sure you have chai ready.
normalised: And if all else fails, you can always fall back on your extensive knowledge of Indian history, thanks to your B-A, and impress everyone at parties with your trivia! Just make sure you have chai ready.
